subject: AI
title: Self-Consistency
description: Run the same prompt multiple times and pick the majority answer.

hook.text: The model gets the math problem right 70% of the time. Run it five times, take the majority answer, and accuracy jumps to 90%.

buildup.text: Self-consistency generates multiple chain-of-thought paths at higher temperature, then picks the most frequent final answer. It's like asking five people and going with the consensus.

discovery.text: The reasoning paths can be wildly different but converge on the same answer. If three out of five attempts say '42,' that's more reliable than any single run.

twist.text: It costs 5x the tokens since you run the prompt multiple times. Only use it when correctness is critical ‚Äî exams, financial calculations, code generation.

climax.text: Self-consistency trades compute for accuracy. When getting it right matters more than getting it cheap, this technique is gold.

punchline.text: One answer might be wrong. Five answers voting? Much harder to fool.

quiz.question: What is the core idea of self-consistency?
options: Generating multiple reasoning paths and picking the majority answer
Using the same prompt template for all tasks
Running the prompt at zero temperature
